articles.title: Trail hunting to be banned as part of new animal welfare strategy
articles.summary: The government says the practice is being used as a "smokescreen" for the hunting of wild animals.
articles.content:
Trail hunting to be banned as part of new animal welfare strategy

The government says it is acting on a manifesto commitment to outlaw a practice being used as a "smokescreen" for the hunting of wild animals. But hunting and countryside bodies say the move was unnecessary and could hurt rural communities.

It has remained legal since the 2004 hunting ban came into force, because it does not explicitly involve the killing of animals.

The practice sees an animal-based scent trail laid for dogs to follow rather than a real animal, while a group of hunters follows the pack on horseback.

Trail hunting is set to be banned in England and Wales as part of a new animal welfare strategy to be published by the government on Monday.

Hunting with hounds has been a tradition in parts of the UK for centuries, but the 2004 Hunting Act placed restrictions on the practice.

The act banned the use of dogs to hunt wild mammals - including foxes, hares, deer and mink - across England and Wales.

Trail hunting involves laying a trail using a rag soaked in animal scent for hounds to chase. The intention is to replicate the pursuit of an animal across the countryside, without the need to kill anything.

In April, anti-hunting group the League Against Cruel Sports said that nearly 1,600 incidents, including 397 reports of foxes being chased, were recorded nationwide during the prior hunting season.

But the chief executive of the Countryside Alliance, Tim Bonner, said revisiting the issue of trail hunting was "completely unnecessary".

He said: "It is unbelievable that the government wants to waste more parliamentary time on hunting.

"This issue was settled 20 years ago as far as Labour was concerned but it does not seem to be able to leave it alone."

Mr Bonner also spoke about the Labour party's relationship with rural constituents, adding: "People across the countryside will be shocked that after Labour's attack on family farms and its neglect of rural communities it thinks banning trail hunting and snares used for fox control are a political priority."

The British Hound Sports Association (BHSA) has previously said trail hunts were "vital" to rural communities as they not only bring in money into the rural economy, but also support mental and physical wellbeing.

One farmer told the BBC: "I would be shunned if I publicly rejected hunting."

They added that banning trail hunting "reinforces the narrative [Labour] don't care and are imposing urban values on people they don't understand".

Ministers will consult on the details of the ban in the new year.

The minister for animal welfare Baroness Hayman said: "In our manifesto we said we would ban trail hunting, and that's exactly what we'll do.

"There are concerns that trail hunting is being used a smokescreen for the hunting of wild animals, and that's not acceptable.

"We are working out the best approach to take the ban forward and will run a consultation to seek views in the new year."

But Conservative chairman Kevin Hollinrake called the ban an "attack on rural Britain and British culture", accusing the government of "punishing the law-abiding majority who support legal trail hunting".

Meanwhile, Reform UK leader Nigel Farage described Labour as "authoritarian control freaks".

Trail hunting is already banned in Scotland. Hunting with dogs remains legal in Northern Ireland.

articles.personality_title: England and Wales to ban trail hunting to protect wild animals
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In England and Wales, hunting wild animals with dogs has been illegal since 2004. However, trail hunting, where dogs follow an animal scent trail instead of a real animal, has remained legal. Some say this practice hides illegal hunting.

**What happened** – The government announced plans to ban trail hunting as part of a new animal welfare strategy. This decision is based on concerns that trail hunting is being used as a cover for hunting wild animals illegally. Ministers will consult on the details of the ban early next year.

**Impact** – Banning trail hunting aims to better protect wild animals by closing a loophole used to disguise illegal hunts. This move shows a stronger commitment to animal welfare. Some countryside groups worry the ban could hurt rural communities that rely on hunting traditions and related activities.

**What's next step** – The government will hold consultations to work out the best way to enforce the ban. After that, new laws will be introduced to make trail hunting illegal in England and Wales.

**One-sentence takeaway** – England and Wales are set to ban trail hunting to stop it from being used as a cover for illegal wild animal hunting and improve animal protection.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'Angleterre et le Pays de Galles interdisent la chasse à l'odeur pour protéger les animaux sauvages
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En Angleterre et au Pays de Galles, la chasse aux animaux sauvages avec des chiens est interdite depuis 2004. Cependant, la chasse à l'odeur, où les chiens suivent une piste parfumée au lieu d'un animal réel, reste légale. Certains disent que cette pratique masque la chasse illégale.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le gouvernement a annoncé son intention d'interdire la chasse à l'odeur dans le cadre d'une nouvelle stratégie de protection animale. Cette décision repose sur des inquiétudes que la chasse à l'odeur soit utilisée pour cacher la chasse illégale d'animaux sauvages. Une consultation publique aura lieu début de l'année prochaine.

**Impact** – L'interdiction vise à mieux protéger les animaux sauvages en fermant une faille qui permet de dissimuler des chasses illégales. Ce geste montre un engagement plus fort pour le bien-être animal. Certains groupes ruraux craignent que cette interdiction nuise aux communautés rurales qui dépendent des traditions de chasse.

**Prochaine étape** – Le gouvernement organisera des consultations pour définir la meilleure façon d'appliquer l'interdiction. Ensuite, de nouvelles lois rendront la chasse à l'odeur illégale en Angleterre et au Pays de Galles.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L'Angleterre et le Pays de Galles vont interdire la chasse à l'odeur pour empêcher son utilisation comme couverture à la chasse illégale et renforcer la protection des animaux.
articles.personality_title_es: Inglaterra y Gales prohibirán la caza con rastreo para proteger a los animales salvajes
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En Inglaterra y Gales, la caza con perros de animales salvajes está prohibida desde 2004. Sin embargo, la caza con rastreo, donde los perros siguen una pista de olor en lugar de un animal real, sigue siendo legal. Algunos dicen que esta práctica oculta la caza ilegal.

**Qué pasó** – El gobierno anunció planes para prohibir la caza con rastreo como parte de una nueva estrategia de bienestar animal. La decisión se basa en preocupaciones de que la caza con rastreo se use para encubrir la caza ilegal de animales salvajes. Se realizarán consultas a principios del próximo año.

**Impacto** – La prohibición busca proteger mejor a los animales salvajes cerrando una laguna que permite ocultar la caza ilegal. Esta medida muestra un compromiso más fuerte con el bienestar animal. Algunos grupos rurales temen que la prohibición afecte a las comunidades que dependen de las tradiciones de caza.

**Próximo paso** – El gobierno llevará a cabo consultas para decidir cómo aplicar mejor la prohibición. Luego, se introducirán nuevas leyes que harán ilegal la caza con rastreo en Inglaterra y Gales.

**Resumen en una frase** – Inglaterra y Gales prohibirán la caza con rastreo para evitar que se use como disfraz para la caza ilegal y mejorar la protección animal.
